elements.content: Through judicious choice of the ligands and patient regulation of the solvent conditions, three unique chiral coordination polymeric isomers have been synthesized. Their structures, gas adsorption, and structural interconversion have been studied. One of the isomers displays dynamic behavior, and its use in the enantioselective separation of chiral alcohols has also been reported.
elements.clean_text: Through judicious choice of the ligands and patient regulation of the solvent conditions, three unique chiral coordination polymeric isomers have been synthesized. Their structures, gas adsorption, and structural interconversion have been studied. One of the isomers displays dynamic behavior, and its use in the enantioselective separation of chiral alcohols has also been reported.

elements.content: Three flexible chiral coordination polymeric isomers based on amino acid derivatives have been synthesized by solvent-controlled self-assembly. Their structures, gas adsorption, and structural interconversion have been studied. One of the isomers displays dynamic behavior, and its use in the enantioselective separation of chiral alcohols has also been reported.
elements.clean_text: Three flexible chiral coordination polymeric isomers based on amino acid derivatives have been synthesized by solvent-controlled self-assembly. Their structures, gas adsorption, and structural interconversion have been studied. One of the isomers displays dynamic behavior, and its use in the enantioselective separation of chiral alcohols has also been reported.

elements.content: Chiral metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), which can be afforded by self-assembly reactions of chiral organic linkers and metal ions, usually exhibit intriguing homochiral structures as well as fascinating potential applications. To date, considerable interest has been focused on the use of chiral MOFs for enantioseparation in virtue of their stable chiral architectures, controllable open cavities and tunable intermolecular interactions. Recent breakthroughs of their applications in the area of chromatographic and membrane-based separation demonstrate their potential applications as a new generation of chiral resolving agents. However, relative researches are still very scarce.
elements.clean_text: Chiral metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), which can be afforded by self-assembly reactions of chiral organic linkers and metal ions, usually exhibit intriguing homochiral structures as well as fascinating potential applications. To date, considerable interest has been focused on the use of chiral MOFs for enantioseparation in virtue of their stable chiral architectures, controllable open cavities and tunable intermolecular interactions. Recent breakthroughs of their applications in the area of chromatographic and membrane-based separation demonstrate their potential applications as a new generation of chiral resolving agents. However, relative researches are still very scarce.

elements.content: A key point to designing chiral MOFs with porous frameworks and enantioseparation properties is to choose the proper chiral building blocks. However, the design and preparation remain challenging mainly because of the limited chiral source and tedious synthetic process of the ligands. Hence, readily available chiral polydentate ligands are highly desired. Amino acids and their derivatives are attractive because of their inherent chirality, inexpensive price, multiple coordination modes, and modifiable structures. In addition, amino acid based MOFs are rich in donors and acceptors for hydrogen-bonding interactions that are of importance for effective enantioselective recognition.
elements.clean_text: A key point to designing chiral MOFs with porous frameworks and enantioseparation properties is to choose the proper chiral building blocks. However, the design and preparation remain challenging mainly because of the limited chiral source and tedious synthetic process of the ligands. Hence, readily available chiral polydentate ligands are highly desired. Amino acids and their derivatives are attractive because of their inherent chirality, inexpensive price, multiple coordination modes, and modifiable structures. In addition, amino acid based MOFs are rich in donors and acceptors for hydrogen-bonding interactions that are of importance for effective enantioselective recognition.

elements.content: Amino acid based chiral MOFs are reported to be increasing each year, but most of them are of condensed packing structures without accessible pores or channels, mainly resulting from the backbone flexibility of the amino acids. To construct open porous architectures, rigid ligands are usually adopted to strengthen the frameworks and pillar cavities. Moreover, synthetic conditions are also needed to regulate patiently. Reaction media are extremely significant because they not only make a great impact on the reactants’ solubility and polarity but also act as templates to induce structural formation and crystallization.
elements.clean_text: Amino acid based chiral MOFs are reported to be increasing each year, but most of them are of condensed packing structures without accessible pores or channels, mainly resulting from the backbone flexibility of the amino acids. To construct open porous architectures, rigid ligands are usually adopted to strengthen the frameworks and pillar cavities. Moreover, synthetic conditions are also needed to regulate patiently. Reaction media are extremely significant because they not only make a great impact on the reactants' solubility and polarity but also act as templates to induce structural formation and crystallization.

elements.content: In this study, rare examples of amino acid based chiral MOFs used for enantioselective adsorption are reported. We employ N,N′-oxalylbis(alanine) (OBAla) as a flexible enantiopure ligand, along with 4,4′-methylenedi-3,5-dimethylpyrazole (H2mbdpz) as a conformationally flexible auxiliary ligand, to construct three homochiral coordination polymeric isomers under different solvent conditions, formulated as Cu2(l-OBAla)(H2mbdpz)2 (1), α-Cu2(l-OBAla)(H2mbdpz) (2), and β-Cu2(l-OBAla)(H2mbdpz)⊃guest (3⊃guest) (Scheme ). The significant role of the solvent in framework formation is further demonstrated by solvent-induced interconversion of compounds 2 and 3. Moreover, compound 3 undergoes a reversible structural transformation during guest exchange and exhibits enantioselective inclusion of aromatic alcohols.
elements.clean_text: In this study, rare examples of amino acid based chiral MOFs used for enantioselective adsorption are reported. We employ N,N'-oxalylbis(alanine) (OBAla) as a flexible enantiopure ligand, along with 4,4'-methylenedi-3,5-dimethylpyrazole (H2mbdpz) as a conformationally flexible auxiliary ligand, to construct three homochiral coordination polymeric isomers under different solvent conditions, formulated as Cu2(l-OBAla)(H2mbdpz)2 (1), α-Cu2(l-OBAla)(H2mbdpz) (2), and β-Cu2(l-OBAla)(H2mbdpz)⊃guest (3⊃guest) (Scheme ). The significant role of the solvent in framework formation is further demonstrated by solvent-induced interconversion of compounds 2 and 3. Moreover, compound 3 undergoes a reversible structural transformation during guest exchange and exhibits enantioselective inclusion of aromatic alcohols.

elements.clean_text: 1  Structures of the Ligands and Subunit      a (a) OBAla ligand; (b) H2mbdpz ligand; (c) Cu2(l-OBAla) subunits.

elements.content:
(a) OBAla ligand; (b) H2mbdpz ligand; (c) Cu2(l-OBAla) subunits.

Hydrothermal reactions of Cu(NO3)2, OBAla, and H2mbdpz in a molar ratio of 2:1:1 at 100 °C for 3 days afford light-green sheet-like crystals of compound 1. When water is replaced with a mixture of EtOH (or CH3CN, DMA)/H2O (1:3, v/v), blue spindle-shaped crystals of compound 2 are obtained. Light-green polyhedral crystals of compound 3 are the main product in the mixture of water and 2-butanol [or other alcohols such as isopropyl alcohol, 2-pentanol, 2-hexanol, 2-heptanol, 1-phenethyl alcohol (1-PEA), 1-phenyl-1-propanol (1-PPP)]. Compounds 1, 2, and 3⊃guest can be easily distinguished by their shape and color (Figure S1 in the , SI). All compounds are insoluble in common organic solvents.
elements.clean_text:
a (a) OBAla ligand; (b) H2mbdpz ligand; (c) Cu2(l-OBAla) subunits.  

Hydrothermal reactions of Cu(NO3)2, OBAla, and H2mbdpz in a molar ratio of 2:1:1 at 100 °C for 3 days afford light-green sheet-like crystals of compound 1. When water is replaced with a mixture of EtOH (or CH3CN, DMA)/H2O (1:3, v/v), blue spindle-shaped crystals of compound 2 are obtained. Light-green polyhedral crystals of compound 3 are the main product in the mixture of water and 2-butanol [or other alcohols such as isopropyl alcohol, 2-pentanol, 2-hexanol, 2-heptanol, 1-phenethyl alcohol (1-PEA), 1-phenyl-1-propanol (1-PPP)]. Compounds 1, 2, and 3⊃guest can be easily distinguished by their shape and color (Figure S1 in the , SI). All compounds are insoluble in common organic solvents.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray crystallographic studies reveal that all of the compounds contain planar Cu2(OBAla) subunits, which are similar to our previous report (Scheme c). In this subunit, a −NH–CO–CO–NH– (N,N′-disubstituted oxamide) core and two terminal carboxyl groups chelate two Cu atoms in a bis-tridentate manner, forming four five-membered rings. Each Cu atom is five-coordinated in a distorted square-pyramidal geometry. Compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1. The adjacent Cu2(OBAla) subunits are linked to each other via the four H2mbdpz ligands to form a 1D loop chain running along the b axis (Figures S22 and S23 in the ).
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray crystallographic studies reveal that all of the compounds contain planar Cu2(OBAla) subunits, which are similar to our previous report (Scheme c). In this subunit, a -NH-CO-CO-NH- (N,N'-disubstituted oxamide) core and two terminal carboxyl groups chelate two Cu atoms in a bis-tridentate manner, forming four five-membered rings. Each Cu atom is five-coordinated in a distorted square-pyramidal geometry. Compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1. The adjacent Cu2(OBAla) subunits are linked to each other via the four H2mbdpz ligands to form a 1D loop chain running along the b axis (Figures S22 and S23 in the ).

elements.content: Compounds 2 and 3⊃2-BuOH have identical coordination modes and crystallize in the chiral space groups P41212 and P43212, respectively. The binuclear copper subunits are connected to each other through bonds contributed by pyrazole N atoms of H2mbdpz ligands in the basal plane, as well as apical Cu–O bonds contributed by carboxyl O atoms of l-OBAla ligands from other Cu2(OBAla) subunits. Therefore, if Cu2(OBAla) is simplified as six-connected nodes, 2 and 3⊃2-BuOH display 3D noninterpenetrating frameworks with lcy topology (Figure S24 in the ). Along the c axis, there are two types of right-handed helical chains in both compounds: a 41 helix composed of Cu2(OBAla) subunits and a 21 helix constructed by the copper subunits and H2mbdpz ligands (Figure S26 in the ). The 21 helix generates a rectangular channel with a small size of 3.2 × 3.2 Å in compound 2, whose cavity is seriously blocked by four methyl groups pointing to the center of the channel (Figure b). However, with methyl groups located on the wall of the tubular channels, compound 3⊃2-BuOH has a channel with a square cross section of approximately 5.7 × 8.1 Å2 (Figure d). PLATON analysis shows that the void space is 24.1% of the total volume in 2. The porosity rises to 34.6% in 3⊃2-BuOH if guest molecules are not included, which is 43% higher than that of 2 (Figure e,f).

The binuclear copper subunits are connected to each other through bonds contributed by pyrazole N atoms of H2mbdpz ligands in the basal plane, as well as apical Cu-O bonds contributed by carboxyl O atoms of l-OBAla ligands from other Cu2(OBAla) subunits. Therefore, if Cu2(OBAla) is simplified as six-connected nodes, 2 and 3⊃2-BuOH display 3D noninterpenetrating frameworks with lcy topology (Figure S24 in the ). Along the c axis, there are two types of right-handed helical chains in both compounds: a 41 helix composed of Cu2(OBAla) subunits and a 21 helix constructed by the copper subunits and H2mbdpz ligands (Figure S26 in the ). The 21 helix generates a rectangular channel with a small size of 3.2 × 3.2 Å in compound 2, whose cavity is seriously blocked by four methyl groups pointing to the center of the channel (Figure b). However, with methyl groups located on the wall of the tubular channels, compound 3⊃2-BuOH has a channel with a square cross section of approximately 5.7 × 8.1 Å2 (Figure d). PLATON analysis shows that the void space is 24.1% of the total volume in 2. The porosity rises to 34.6% in 3⊃2-BuOH if guest molecules are not included, which is 43% higher than that of 2 (Figure e,f).

(e) Space-filling models of 2. (f) Space-filling models of 3 viewed along the c axis (solvent molecules have been omitted for clarity).

elements.content: Close observation reveals that the difference in the conformation of pyrazoles causes dissimilar structural features of compounds 2 and 3⊃2-BuOH. Consequently, the C3 and O3 atoms locate on the opposite side of the Cu2(OBAla) plane in compound 2, while the two atoms reside on the same side in 3⊃2-BuOH (Figure a,c). If guests were not considered, the two compounds would be classified as “conformational isomers”.
elements.clean_text: Close observation reveals that the difference in the conformation of pyrazoles causes dissimilar structural features of compounds 2 and 3⊃2-BuOH. Consequently, the C3 and O3 atoms locate on the opposite side of the Cu2(OBAla) plane in compound 2, while the two atoms reside on the same side in 3⊃2-BuOH (Figure a,c). If guests were not considered, the two compounds would be classified as "conformational isomers".

elements.content: The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of all compounds are in good agreement with the simulated ones, suggesting the purity of the products (Figure S9 in the ). The circular dichroism (CD) curves of the three compounds, produced from l- or d-OBAla, are mirror images of each other, which suggests their enantiomeric nature (Figure S2 in the ). Notably, the different CD curves of isomers 2 and 3 allow us to discern them by CD spectra.
elements.clean_text: The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of all compounds are in good agreement with the simulated ones, suggesting the purity of the products (Figure S9 in the ). The circular dichroism (CD) curves of the three compounds, produced from l- or d-OBAla, are mirror images of each other, which suggests their enantiomeric nature (Figure S2 in the ). Notably, the different CD curves of isomers 2 and 3 allow us to discern them by CD spectra.

elements.content: The guest molecules, 2-butanol, in compound 3⊃2-BuOH are disordered in structure. However, the high boiling guest molecules in compounds 3⊃1-PEA and 3⊃1-PPP have been clearly determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (Figure S27 in the ). Compounds 3⊃1-PEA and 3⊃1-PPP crystallize in the space group P21212 with skeletons that are nearly identical with that of 3⊃2-BuOH. Each asymmetric unit involves one guest molecule. According to the crystallography data that we collected, the chiral framework of l-3 attracts (R)-1-PEA and (S)-1-PPP, while d-3 adsorbs (S)-1-PEA and (R)-1-PPP.
elements.clean_text: The guest molecules, 2-butanol, in compound 3⊃2-BuOH are disordered in structure. However, the high boiling guest molecules in compounds 3⊃1-PEA and 3⊃1-PPP have been clearly determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (Figure S27 in the ). Compounds 3⊃1-PEA and 3⊃1-PPP crystallize in the space group P21212 with skeletons that are nearly identical with that of 3⊃2-BuOH. Each asymmetric unit involves one guest molecule. According to the crystallography data that we collected, the chiral framework of l-3 attracts (R)-1-PEA and (S)-1-PPP, while d-3 adsorbs (S)-1-PEA and (R)-1-PPP.

elements.content: Because the solvent is the only variable in the reaction conditions, some empirical trends are found according to the relationship between the solvent and final products (Table S12 in the ). Polar solvents prompt the assembly of 1 and 2, while lower polar solvents result in the formation of 3. Small solvent molecules lead to the construction of dense packing structures of 2; however, molecules that are larger than C5 can be served as templates to generate the large pores of 3.
elements.clean_text: Because the solvent is the only variable in the reaction conditions, some empirical trends are found according to the relationship between the solvent and final products (Table S12 in the ). Polar solvents prompt the assembly of 1 and 2, while lower polar solvents result in the formation of 3. Small solvent molecules lead to the construction of dense packing structures of 2; however, molecules that are larger than C5 can be served as templates to generate the large pores of 3.

elements.content: Not only in the forming stage do the solvents have an influence on the thermal postprocessing of formed crystals. It has been observed that the blue crystals of 2 can convert to green powders of 3⊃1-PEA in the H2O/1-PEA mixture for 2 days under hydrothermal conditions. Similarly, 3 can also convert to 2 by heating in the H2O/EtOH mixtures (Figure a). The PXRD patterns and CD spectra before and after solvothermal reactions further demonstrate the occurrence of interconversion (Figures S3, S4, S14, and S15 in the ). Because the compound experiences a process of bond breaking and regeneration, we consider that interconversion is not through a single crystal-to-single crystal transformation but via a decomposition and reconstruction mechanism.
elements.clean_text: Not only in the forming stage do the solvents have an influence on the thermal postprocessing of formed crystals. It has been observed that the blue crystals of 2 can convert to green powders of 3⊃1-PEA in the H2O/1-PEA mixture for 2 days under hydrothermal conditions. Similarly, 3 can also convert to 2 by heating in the H2O/EtOH mixtures (Figure a). The PXRD patterns and CD spectra before and after solvothermal reactions further demonstrate the occurrence of interconversion (Figures S3, S4, S14, and S15 in the ). Because the compound experiences a process of bond breaking and regeneration, we consider that interconversion is not through a single crystal-to-single crystal transformation but via a decomposition and reconstruction mechanism.

elements.content: (a) Photographs of the interconversion process of 2 and 3⊃1-PEA. (b) PXRD patterns for as-synthesized 3⊃1-PEA, desolvated 3⊃1-PEA (3′), and 3′ immersed in 1-PEA at room temperature and 100 °C for 3 days.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Photographs of the interconversion process of 2 and 3⊃1-PEA. (b) PXRD patterns for as-synthesized 3⊃1-PEA, desolvated 3⊃1-PEA (3'), and 3' immersed in 1-PEA at room temperature and 100 °C for 3 days.

elements.content: To investigate the crystal stability upon removal of the solvents, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) and PXRD experiments at variable temperatures are carried out. TGA show that the frameworks of compounds 1–3 are stable up to 240 °C. Before framework collapse, compound 3⊃guest loses one solvent molecule consistent with the formula (Figures S5–S7 in the ). Notably, when heating at 120 °C, the PXRD pattern of desolvated 3⊃2-BuOH is distinct from the original pattern. Meanwhile, the crystals become opaque and are unsuitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Removal of the high-boiling-point solvent in 3⊃1-PEA, 3⊃1-PPP, or 3⊃2-PenOH by solvent exchange with methanol also leads to different PXRD patterns, which are close to that of desolvated 3⊃2-BuOH (Figures S11 and S12 in the ). These phenomena reveal that no matter which guests are included, removing guests from 3 will generate a desolvated framework of 3′.
elements.clean_text: To investigate the crystal stability upon removal of the solvents, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) and PXRD experiments at variable temperatures are carried out. TGA show that the frameworks of compounds 1-3 are stable up to 240 °C. Before framework collapse, compound 3⊃guest loses one solvent molecule consistent with the formula (Figures S5-S7 in the ). Notably, when heating at 120 °C, the PXRD pattern of desolvated 3⊃2-BuOH is distinct from the original pattern. Meanwhile, the crystals become opaque and are unsuitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Removal of the high-boiling-point solvent in 3⊃1-PEA, 3⊃1-PPP, or 3⊃2-PenOH by solvent exchange with methanol also leads to different PXRD patterns, which are close to that of desolvated 3⊃2-BuOH (Figures S11 and S12 in the ). These phenomena reveal that no matter which guests are included, removing guests from 3 will generate a desolvated framework of 3'.

elements.content: Furthermore, gas adsorption experiments confirm the structural transformation by the detection of porosity. Activated by heating at 120 °C under vacuum, compound 2 exhibits a type I behavior with a moderate H2 uptake of 111 cm3 g–1 at 760 mmHg, while desolvated 3⊃2-BuOH adsorbed none of the three gas probes, including H2, N2, and CO2 (Figure S16 in the ). The loss of the adsorption capacity of 3 can be attributed to the remarkable shrinking of the pore size during desolvation. Hence, the guest molecules have a profound effect on sustaining and stabilizing the open frameworks.
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, gas adsorption experiments confirm the structural transformation by the detection of porosity. Activated by heating at 120 °C under vacuum, compound 2 exhibits a type I behavior with a moderate H2 uptake of 111 cm3 g-1 at 760 mmHg, while desolvated 3⊃2-BuOH adsorbed none of the three gas probes, including H2, N2, and CO2 (Figure S16 in the ). The loss of the adsorption capacity of 3 can be attributed to the remarkable shrinking of the pore size during desolvation. Hence, the guest molecules have a profound effect on sustaining and stabilizing the open frameworks.

elements.content: Interestingly, the guests can infiltrate the framework of 3′ and regenerate 3⊃guest. This process is clearly verified by the PXRD patterns before and after readsorption. Take 3⊃1-PEA for example (Figure b). The strongest peak moves from 10.6° to 11.5° upon loss of guests, and then it returns to 10.6° after 3′ is immersed in 1-PEA for 3 days at 80 °C, following with the emergence of three characteristic peaks of 3⊃1-PEA at 2θ = 8.19°, 8.70°, and 9.13°. 1-PPP can also be readsorbed by compound 3′ (Figure S13 in the ). However, the regeneration process cannot take place at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, the guests can infiltrate the framework of 3' and regenerate 3⊃guest. This process is clearly verified by the PXRD patterns before and after readsorption. Take 3⊃1-PEA for example (Figure b). The strongest peak moves from 10.6° to 11.5° upon loss of guests, and then it returns to 10.6° after 3' is immersed in 1-PEA for 3 days at 80 °C, following with the emergence of three characteristic peaks of 3⊃1-PEA at 2θ = 8.19°, 8.70°, and 9.13°. 1-PPP can also be readsorbed by compound 3' (Figure S13 in the ). However, the regeneration process cannot take place at room temperature.

elements.content: Hydrogen bonds between 1-PEA guests (yellow molecules) and the 1D channel in 3⊃1-PEA (H atoms have been omitted for clarity except hydroxy H).
elements.clean_text: 3  Hydrogen bonds between 1-PEA guests (yellow molecules) and the 1D channel in 3⊃1-PEA (H atoms have been omitted for clarity except hydroxy H).

elements.content: The reversible and dynamic transition of compound 3 prompts us to explore its resolution application on small chiral alcohols, such as 1-PEA, 1-PPP, and 1-(2-naphthyl)ethanol (NPE). l-3 can enantioselectively include 1-PEA (43.4% ee, in favor of the R isomer) and 1-PPP (36.0% ee, in favor of the S isomer). The desorbed guests from d-3 favor the opposite isomers, which agree with the crystal structures described above (Table S13 and Figures S17–S20 in the ). However, owing to the size effect, the ee values for desorbed NPE are very low. Moreover, desolvated 3′ is able to resolvate and be tested in the next cycle, but the ee values decrease to 34.4% (for 1-PEA) and 26.0% (for 1-PPP), which may be caused by certain loss of crystallinity during solvent exchange and framework transformation (Figure S21 in the ).
elements.clean_text: The reversible and dynamic transition of compound 3 prompts us to explore its resolution application on small chiral alcohols, such as 1-PEA, 1-PPP, and 1-(2-naphthyl)ethanol (NPE). l-3 can enantioselectively include 1-PEA (43.4% ee, in favor of the R isomer) and 1-PPP (36.0% ee, in favor of the S isomer). The desorbed guests from d-3 favor the opposite isomers, which agree with the crystal structures described above (Table S13 and Figures S17-S20 in the ). However, owing to the size effect, the ee values for desorbed NPE are very low. Moreover, desolvated 3' is able to resolvate and be tested in the next cycle, but the ee values decrease to 34.4% (for 1-PEA) and 26.0% (for 1-PPP), which may be caused by certain loss of crystallinity during solvent exchange and framework transformation (Figure S21 in the ).

elements.content: The enantioselectivity can be attributed to hydrogen-bonding interactions between O atom (from oxamide) and hydroxyl groups (from 1-PEA or 1-PPP), which make the guest molecules orderly dock in the channels (Figure ). The O···O distances of O–H···O hydrogen bonds are in the range of 2.9802–3.1348 Å, but the overall affinity of 3 toward alcohol is not strong enough for complete resolution of racemates, resulting in a moderate recognition capability.
elements.clean_text: The enantioselectivity can be attributed to hydrogen-bonding interactions between O atom (from oxamide) and hydroxyl groups (from 1-PEA or 1-PPP), which make the guest molecules orderly dock in the channels (Figure ). The O⋅⋅⋅O distances of O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds are in the range of 2.9802-3.1348 Å, but the overall affinity of 3 toward alcohol is not strong enough for complete resolution of racemates, resulting in a moderate recognition capability.

elements.content: The studies in the application of chiral MOFs for chiral aromatic alcohol resolution are extremely rare because large pores are required for aromatic alcohols to accommodate. The enantioselective capability of compound 3 for 1-PEA is lower than that of M′MOF-3–7 but higher than that of [Zn2(bdc)(S-lac)(dmf)], M′MOF-2 and Cd2(l-cps)4(bix)4. This work not only provides valuable clues for the convenient synthesis of porous chiral MOFs but also explores a new way to design chromatographic stationary phase materials using homochiral MOFs containing inexpensive amino acid derivatives.
elements.clean_text: The studies in the application of chiral MOFs for chiral aromatic alcohol resolution are extremely rare because large pores are required for aromatic alcohols to accommodate. The enantioselective capability of compound 3 for 1-PEA is lower than that of M'MOF-3-7 but higher than that of [Zn2(bdc)(S-lac)(dmf)], M'MOF-2 and Cd2(l-cps)4(bix)4. This work not only provides valuable clues for the convenient synthesis of porous chiral MOFs but also explores a new way to design chromatographic stationary phase materials using homochiral MOFs containing inexpensive amino acid derivatives.

cln_elements.content:
Compounds 2 and 3⊃2-BuOH have identical coordination modes and crystallize in the chiral space groups P41212 and P43212, respectively. The binuclear copper subunits are connected to each other through bonds contributed by pyrazole N atoms of H2mbdpz ligands in the basal plane, as well as apical Cu–O bonds contributed by carboxyl O atoms of l-OBAla ligands from other Cu2(OBAla) subunits. Therefore, if Cu2(OBAla) is simplified as six-connected nodes, 2 and 3⊃2-BuOH display 3D noninterpenetrating frameworks with lcy topology (Figure S24 in the ). Along the c axis, there are two types of right-handed helical chains in both compounds: a 41 helix composed of Cu2(OBAla) subunits and a 21 helix constructed by the copper subunits and H2mbdpz ligands (Figure S26 in the ). The 21 helix generates a rectangular channel with a small size of 3.2 × 3.2 Å in compound 2, whose cavity is seriously blocked by four methyl groups pointing to the center of the channel (Figure b). However, with methyl groups located on the wall of the tubular channels, compound 3⊃2-BuOH has a channel with a square cross section of approximately 5.7 × 8.1 Å2 (Figure d). PLATON analysis shows that the void space is 24.1% of the total volume in 2. The porosity rises to 34.6% in 3⊃2-BuOH if guest molecules are not included, which is 43% higher than that of 2 (Figure e,f).

Furthermore, gas adsorption experiments confirm the structural transformation by the detection of porosity. Activated by heating at 120 °C under vacuum, compound 2 exhibits a type I behavior with a moderate H2 uptake of 111 cm3 g–1 at 760 mmHg, while desolvated 3⊃2-BuOH adsorbed none of the three gas probes, including H2, N2, and CO2 (Figure S16 in the ). The loss of the adsorption capacity of 3 can be attributed to the remarkable shrinking of the pore size during desolvation. Hence, the guest molecules have a profound effect on sustaining and stabilizing the open frameworks.

The binuclear copper subunits are connected to each other through bonds contributed by pyrazole N atoms of H2mbdpz ligands in the basal plane, as well as apical Cu-O bonds contributed by carboxyl O atoms of l-OBAla ligands from other Cu2(OBAla) subunits. Therefore, if Cu2(OBAla) is simplified as six-connected nodes, 2 and 3⊃2-BuOH display 3D noninterpenetrating frameworks with lcy topology (Figure S24 in the ). Along the c axis, there are two types of right-handed helical chains in both compounds: a 41 helix composed of Cu2(OBAla) subunits and a 21 helix constructed by the copper subunits and H2mbdpz ligands (Figure S26 in the ). The 21 helix generates a rectangular channel with a small size of 3.2 × 3.2 Å in compound 2, whose cavity is seriously blocked by four methyl groups pointing to the center of the channel (Figure b). However, with methyl groups located on the wall of the tubular channels, compound 3⊃2-BuOH has a channel with a square cross section of approximately 5.7 × 8.1 Å2 (Figure d). PLATON analysis shows that the void space is 24.1% of the total volume in 2. The porosity rises to 34.6% in 3⊃2-BuOH if guest molecules are not included, which is 43% higher than that of 2 (Figure e,f).

Furthermore, gas adsorption experiments confirm the structural transformation by the detection of porosity. Activated by heating at 120 °C under vacuum, compound 2 exhibits a type I behavior with a moderate H2 uptake of 111 cm3 g-1 at 760 mmHg, while desolvated 3⊃2-BuOH adsorbed none of the three gas probes, including H2, N2, and CO2 (Figure S16 in the ). The loss of the adsorption capacity of 3 can be attributed to the remarkable shrinking of the pore size during desolvation. Hence, the guest molecules have a profound effect on sustaining and stabilizing the open frameworks.

gas adsorption.condition: no adsorption of H2, N2, and CO2
